questions.text: Which of the following formulas gives the oxygen extraction ratio (OER) of a substance?
questions.explanation:
Factor

Key Influences

Impact on OER

Oxygen Delivery (DO2)

Cardiac output, Hemoglobin, SpO₂

Decrease leads to increased OER

Oxygen Consumption (VO2)

Metabolic demands (exercise, sepsis)

Increase without DO₂ increase elevates OER

Blood Flow

Vascular diseases, Shock states

Altered blood flow dynamics affect OER

Physiological Conditions

Hypoxia, Anemia, Hypercapnia

Hypoxia increases OER

Dialysis

Hemodynamic changes during dialysis

Higher OER linked to intradialytic hypotension

Age and Health Status

Age-related cardiovascular/respiratory changes

Reduced cardiac output and hemoglobin levels impact OER

Medications/
Treatments

Vasodilators, Inotropes, Mechanical ventilation

Influence blood flow and oxygen delivery, affecting OER

questions.text: Which of the following contributes to the higher hematocrit in venous blood than arterial blood?

options.label: A
options.text: Lower Plasma Volume in venous blood

options.label: B
options.text: Chloride shift causing red blood cell swelling

options.label: C
options.text: Greater carbon dioxide content in venous blood

questions.explanation:
Feature

Chloride shift

Reverse chloride shift

Location

Tissues

Lungs

Process

CO₂ enters RBCs, forming H₂CO₃ → H⁺ + HCO₃⁻. HCO₃⁻ exits in exchange for Cl⁻

CO₂ exits RBCs. HCO₃⁻ re-enters RBCs in exchange for Cl⁻

Effect on RBCs

Chloride influx causes water influx, swelling RBCs

Chloride efflux balances HCO₃⁻ re-entry, CO₂ is released

Impact on haematocrit

Increases hematocrit due to RBC swelling

Primarily facilitates CO₂ release, indirectly affecting hematocrit

questions.text: What is the significance of the Haldane effect?

options.label: A
options.text: Oxygenation promotes CO₂ release in the lungs.

options.label: B
options.text: Deoxygenation enhances oxygen uptake in tissues.

options.label: C
options.text: CO₂ binding boosts oxygen release in tissues.

options.label: D
options.text: Haemoglobin buffers blood pH by binding hydrogen ions.

questions.correct_answer: A. Oxygenation promotes CO₂ release in the lungs.
questions.explanation:
Concept

The binding of oxygen (O2) to haemoglobin in the lungs promotes the release of carbon dioxide (CO2) from the blood.

Mechanism
  • When O2 binds to haemoglobin, it becomes a stronger acid.
  • Increased acidity reduces haemoglobin's tendency to bind CO2 (carbaminohemoglobin), releasing CO2 into the blood.
  • Increased acidity causes haemoglobin to release hydrogen ions (H+), which combine with bicarbonate ions (HCO3-) to form carbonic acid (H2CO3).
  • Carbonic acid dissociates into water and CO2, exhaling into the alveoli.

Effects
  • In the lungs, high partial pressure of oxygen (PO2) shifts the CO2 dissociation curve, causing more CO2 to be released from the blood.
  • This effect approximately doubled the amount of CO2 released in the lungs and picked up in the tissues compared to without this shift.
  • The CO2 dissociation curve shows the effect quantitatively.

Significance

The Haldane Effect is more quantitatively significant in promoting CO2 transport compared to the Bohr effect's role in promoting O2 transport.

questions.text: Which phenomenon explains the release of oxygen from haemoglobin in response to high carbon dioxide concentrations at the tissue level?
questions.explanation:
Bohr Effect

A shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve to the right in response to increases in blood CO2 and H+ levels has a significant effect by enhancing the release of O2 from the blood in the tissues and enhancing oxygenation of the blood in the lungs

Mechanism
  • Increase in CO2: CO2 diffuses from tissues into the blood, forming carbonic acid (H₂CO₃), dissociating into H+ and HCO3-. This increase in H+ lowers blood pH.
  • Decrease in pH: Lower pH shifts the oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curve to the right, causing haemoglobin to release O2 more readily.

Effects in Tissues

Higher CO2 and lower pH cause haemoglobin to release O2, delivering more O2 to metabolically active tissues.

Effects in Lungs

Expelling CO2 in the lungs decreases blood CO2 levels and increases pH, shifting the dissociation curve to the left and allowing haemoglobin to bind O2 more readily for transport.

Factors Influencing the Bohr Effect
  • Increased CO2 concentration
  • Increased blood temperature
  • Increased 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate (BPG) concentration: BPG binds to haemoglobin, reducing its affinity for O2 and promoting O2 release.

Double bohr effect

Details

Location

Placenta where maternal and fetal circulation meet.

Fetal Blood Flow

Umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood with high CO2 from the fetus to placenta

CO2 Diffusion

CO2 diffuses from fetal to maternal blood

Effect on Fetal Blood
  • CO2 decreases, blood becomes alkaline
  • Oxygen dissociation curve shifts left

Effect on Maternal Blood
  • CO2 increases, blood becomes acidic
  • Oxygen dissociation curve shifts right

Clinical Significance

Enhances oxygen transfer from mother to fetus, improving fetal oxygenation

questions.text: In which form is carbon dioxide predominantly transported in the blood?
Which of the following solutions is considered best for blood storage?
What is the shape of the oxygen dissociation curve for myoglobin?
Which of the following statements is true regarding the Luebering-Rapoport pathway?

options.label: A
options.text: It reduces the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen by producing 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG).

options.label: B
options.text: It generates NADPH as a key product and decreases the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen

options.label: C
options.text: It functions to increase the ATP yield of glycolysis in red blood cells.

options.label: D
options.text: It involves the enzyme hexokinase to initiate the pathway.

questions.correct_answer: A. It reduces the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen by producing 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG).

questions.text: A patient has a haemoglobin concentration of 15 g/dL. Calculate the oxygen-carrying capacity of the patient's blood.
What is the cause of this shift in the hemoglobin-oxygen (Hb-O 2 ) dissociation curve given below?
questions.explanation:
Left Shift - Higher O2 affinity

Right Shift - Reduced O2 affinity
  • Alkalosis.
  • Decreased pCO2.
  • Decreased 2,3-DPG.
  • Hypothermia.
  • Methaemoglobin.
  • Carboxyhaemoglobin.
  • Foetal haemoglobin.
  • Acidosis.
  • Increased pCO2.
  • Increased 2,3-DPG.
  • Hyperthermia.
  • Sulfhaemoglobin.
  • Chronic anaemia.

questions.text: Select the correct statements from the following The binding of one oxygen molecule to Hb decreases the affinity of the remaining heme groups for oxygen. Hb shifts from the Tense (T) state to the Relaxed (R) state upon oxygen binding, increasing oxygen affinity. At low PO 2 , small changes in PO 2 lead to large changes in oxygen saturation. At moderate PO 2 , the dissociation curve is steep, meaning small increases in PO 2 results in large increase in oxygen saturation.
questions.explanation:
PO2 Levels

Oxygen Saturation

Affinity for Oxygen

Low

Slow increase

Low (T state)

Moderate

Steep increase

High (cooperative)

High

Plateau

Approaching full saturation

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the oxygen-hemoglobin (O 2 -Hb) dissociation curve except?

options.label: B
options.text: The plateau phase ranges from 10-60 mm Hg.

options.label: C
options.text: The steep phase ensures efficient oxygen delivery to tissues even with small drops in PO 2 .

options.label: D
options.text: P 50 assesses the binding affinity of haemoglobin for oxygen.

questions.correct_answer: B. The plateau phase ranges from 10-60 mm Hg.
questions.explanation:
Steep phase

Plateau phase

Range

10-60 mm Hg

60-100 mm Hg

Characteristics
  • A rapid increase in Hb saturation.
  • Hb ~90% saturated at PO2 of 60 mm Hg.
  • Curve flattens.
  • Small increase in Hb saturation despite PO2 rise.

Significance
  • The steep phase (10-60 mm Hg PO₂) ensures efficient oxygen unloading, where small PO₂ drops cause significant O₂ release, crucial for active muscles and hypoxic conditions (Option C ruled out)
  • It provides a safety buffer.
  • It maintains high Hb saturation (~90%) despite moderate PO2 decreases.
  • It ensures stable oxygen delivery under varying conditions.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the respiratory unit?
What is the major mode of transport for oxygen in the blood?

options.label: B
options.text: Bound to haemoglobin in red blood cells

questions.correct_answer: B. Bound to haemoglobin in red blood cells

questions.text: Which of the following describes Henry's law?

options.label: A
options.text: The volume of a gas is inversely proportional to its pressure at constant temperature.

options.label: B
options.text: A gas's effusion rate is inversely proportional to the square root of its molar mass.

options.label: C
options.text: The solubility of a gas in a liquid is directly proportional to the partial pressure of the gas above the liquid at a constant temperature.

options.label: D
options.text: The volume of a gas is directly proportional to its temperature at constant pressure

questions.correct_answer: C. The solubility of a gas in a liquid is directly proportional to the partial pressure of the gas above the liquid at a constant temperature.
questions.explanation:
Gas

Solubility Coefficient

Oxygen

0.024

Carbon Dioxide

0.57

Carbon Monoxide

0.018

Nitrogen

0.012

Helium

0.008

options.label: D
options.text: Any of the above, depending on the type of gas

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is admitted to the hospital with severe shortness of breath. Arterial blood gas analysis shows an oxygen content of 16 ml/dl, while the mixed venous blood sample shows an oxygen content of 12 ml/dl. The pulmonary capillary oxygen content is determined to be 20 ml/dl. Calculate the percentage of cardiac output shunt for this patient.
Nitrous oxide is classified as a perfusion-limited gas. What does this imply about its diffusion properties in the lungs?

options.label: A
options.text: N 2 O uptake into pulmonary capillaries is dependent on the amount of blood flowing through it

options.label: B
options.text: N 2 O uptake into pulmonary capillaries is dependent on temperature

options.label: C
options.text: N 2 O uptake into pulmonary capillaries is dependent on atmospheric pressure

questions.correct_answer: A. N 2 O uptake into pulmonary capillaries is dependent on the amount of blood flowing through it
questions.explanation:
Gas Type

Explanation

Example

Diffusion-Limited Gas
  • The diffusion process limits the transfer
  • Diffusing capacity for CO (DLCO) is used to measure the diffusing capacity of the lungs

CO

Perfusion-Limited Gas

The amount of gas taken up is dependent on blood flow (perfusion) through pulmonary capillaries

N2O

Intermediate Case

Uptake is primarily perfusion-limited under normal conditions.

O2

questions.text: Calculate the alveolar oxygen tension (PAO 2 ) for a patient with a barometric pressure (P atm ) of 760 mmHg, a water vapour pressure (P H2O ) of 47 mmHg, an inspired oxygen fraction (FiO2) of 0.21, and an arterial carbon dioxide tension (PACO 2 ) of 40 mmHg. Assume the respiratory quotient (R.Q) is 0.8.

During a pulmonary function test, it is noted that the diffusion equilibrium for oxygen is reached at ⅓ rd of the transit time in the pulmonary capillary. Based on the information provided in the diagram, at what point during the red blood cell's transit through the pulmonary capillary is diffusion equilibrium for oxygen reached?
Carbon dioxide (CO 2 ) diffuses more rapidly than oxygen (O 2 ) primarily due to which of the following properties?

options.label: D
options.text: Higher partial pressure in the alveoli

questions.text: A 65-year-old male has had progressive difficulty breathing over the past year. He reports a persistent dry cough and fatigue. He has no history of smoking or exposure to occupational hazards. On examination, he has fine crackles at the lung bases and clubbing of the fingers. PFT reveals a restrictive pattern. An HRCT scan of the chest shows honeycombing and reticular opacities, predominantly in the lower lobes. This condition primarily affects which aspect of the respiratory membrane?

A 65-year-old male with a 40-year history of heavy smoking presents with progressive shortness of breath and a chronic cough. On examination, he has a barrel-shaped chest and decreased breath sounds bilaterally. Pulmonary function tests show an FEV1/FVC ratio of 0.55 and a significantly decreased DL CO . Which of the following is the most likely reason for the decreased DLCO in this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Increased thickness of the alveolar-capillary membrane

questions.correct_answer: A. Loss of alveolar surface area
questions.explanation:
Procedure
  • Inhale gas mixture (CO and helium)
  • Hold breath for ~10 seconds
  • Exhale and measure CO concentration

Factors Affecting DLCO
  • Lung Volume: Lower volumes decrease DLCO (e.g., restrictive lung diseases)
  • Hemoglobin Level: Anemia lowers DLCO; polycythemia increases DLCO
  • Carboxyhemoglobin Levels: Elevated in smokers, reducing DLCO
  • Alveolar Surface Area: Reduced in emphysema, decreasing DLCO
  • Pulmonary Blood Flow: Reduced flow (e.g., pulmonary hypertension) decreases DLCO

Clinical Interpretation
  • Reduced DLCO: Interstitial lung disease, emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis, pulmonary vascular disease, anemia
  • Increased DLCO: Polycythemia, asthma, left-to-right cardiac shunts

Significance in Clinical Practice
  • Differentiate obstructive vs restrictive lung diseases
  • Assess disease extent in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, sarcoidosis

questions.text: Which of the following factors does NOT affect the rate of diffusion in the lung according to Fick's Law? Thickness of the alveolar-capillary membrane Diameter of the bronchiole Surface area of the alveolar-capillary membrane Partial pressure gradient of the gases Temperature Solubility of the Gas
questions.explanation:
Surface Area of the Membrane
  • The greater the surface area available for diffusion, the higher the rate of gas exchange.
  • In diseases like emphysema, where alveolar surface area is reduced, diffusion capacity decreases.

Concentration Gradient
  • A steeper gradient (difference in partial pressures between the alveoli and the blood) increases the diffusion rate.
  • For example, if the alveolar partial pressure of oxygen is high compared to the blood, oxygen will diffuse more rapidly.

Thickness of the Membrane
  • The thinner the membrane (alveolar-capillary membrane), the faster the diffusion rate.
  • Conditions like pulmonary fibrosis increase membrane thickness and reduce diffusion capacity.

Diffusion Coefficient of the Gas
  • Different gases diffuse at different rates.
  • For example, CO2 diffuses more readily than O2 due to its higher diffusion coefficient.

Temperature and Pressure

Higher temperatures increase the diffusion rate, and barometric pressure changes can also influence diffusion rates.

Solubility of the Gas

Gases more soluble in blood (like CO2) will diffuse more readily than gases with lower solubility (like O2).
